pageData.text: Microbes are practically everywhere in our environment, including our food. Some microbes found in food can result in spoilage and/or human disease. Such microbes need to be removed or killed before these food products are considered safe for human consumption. This is done by cleaning or cooking the food product to eliminate or reduce the microbe count to a safe level. However, other microbes are used for food production. Examples of foods produced by microbial action include cheese, yogurt, wine, and beer. In these instances, bacteria and fungi are used to modify the properties of the original food to create another food with different properties. In this investigation, yogurt will be made from milk as a result of bacterial <button class='glossary-text'>fermentation</button>.

pageData.subTitle: Overview Video: Food Microbiology: Creating Yogurt

text: Describe the principles of microbe use in food production and the effect of nutrients on microbial growth.
Explain how bacterial <button class='glossary-text'>fermentation</button> creates yogurt from milk.
Report the changes in pH and consistency associated with the transformation of milk into yogurt.

pageData.text: Cultures all over the world have used <button class='glossary-text'>fermentation</button> to preserve food for centuries. Ancient Chinese fermented many different fruits, grains, meats, and vegetables to produce different sauces, called jan. It is thought that these sauces laid the foundation for what is known today as soy sauce. Traditionally, soy sauce contains fermented soybeans, roasted grains, brine, and Aspergillus – a type of fungi.

The traditional method of making soy sauce is very labor-intensive. First, the soybeans are steamed, and the grains are roasted. The soybeans and grains are then mixed and crushed, cooled down, put in a vat, and inoculated with Aspergillus. After 3-7 days, the brine is added, and <button class='glossary-text'>lactic acid</button> bacteria and yeast continue fermentation. This process can take months. The longer the fermentation process is allowed to occur the more complex the flavor of the soy sauce will be. The big wooden vats of the fermenting sauce are manually aerated with long wooden paddles during the fermentation process.

pageData.desc: A metal spoon filled with a dark sauce.
pageData.altText: A metal spoon filled with a dark sauce.

pageData.text: Microbes can be used for food production. One of the earliest instances of using microbes to produce food is making yogurt from milk. When naturally-occurring bacteria are added to milk, its consistency becomes thicker, and its flavor becomes tangy. With just a few additional steps, bacteria can convert milk into cheese.

Milk contains a sugar called , a combination of the sugars and , which can be . Fermentation is a metabolic process that occurs in the absence of oxygen during which sugars are used for energy. During fermentation, an enzyme called breaks down lactose. This enzyme is present in bacteria that are added to the milk, namely Lactobacillus acidophilus and Streptococcus thermophilus. The fermentation process will generate the molecules and (Figure 1). Lactic acid lowers the pH of milk, giving yogurt its characteristic tartness.

The presence of acid also changes the way some proteins are folded. This affects one of the most common proteins present in milk, casein. The lower pH causes casein to form clumps, and the clumps form the <button class='glossary-text'>curd</button>, which is the thicker substance of yogurt. Curdling leaves a watery liquid that does not contain clumps called <button class='glossary-text'>whey</button>.

pageData.desc: Figure 1: The biochemical pathway of fermentation.
pageData.altText: Figure 1: The biochemical pathway of fermentation.

pageData.text: Streptococcus thermophilus lacks the necessary enzymes to process galactose whereas Lactobacillus acidophilus can process galactose but has a preference for glucose. This results in a buildup of the sugar galactose, which adds sweetness to the yogurt. This sweetness, combined with the tartness caused by the lower pH, gives yogurt its characteristic taste. Fruits and other products may be added to modify the taste of yogurt, resulting in the wide variety of yogurt flavors available in stores today.

Streptococcus thermophilus and Lactobacillus acidophilus are not the only microbes present in milk. Fresh milk from the cow contains a wide variety of microbes. Many of these microbes are capable of converting into . When these microbes remain in milk, they will consume lactose and produce lactic acid, thus turning the milk sour. In addition to souring the milk, many of these microbes can be harmful to human health. To ensure milk products are safe for human consumption and can be stored for longer periods of time, most milk microbes are killed by a process called . In this process, milk is heated to 62.8° C (145° F) for 30 minutes or 71.7° C (161° F) for 15 seconds in order to meet pasteurization standards set forth by the Food and Drug Administration (FDA).

In this investigation, Streptococcus thermophilus and Lactobacillus acidophilus are obtained from commercially available yogurt. It is important to use a yogurt that contains living cultures (a yogurt without living cultures will not work for this investigation). This information can be found on the yogurt container. The yogurt will be used as a starter culture and be added to milk to produce yogurt.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Milk contains a sugar called lactose, a combination of the sugars glucose and galactose, which can be fermented. Fermentation is a metabolic process that occurs in the absence of oxygen during which sugars are used for energy. During fermentation, an enzyme called lactase breaks down lactose. This enzyme is present in bacteria that are added to the milk, namely Lactobacillus acidophilus and Streptococcus thermophilus. The fermentation process will generate the molecules acetaldehyde and lactic acid. Lactic acid lowers the pH of milk, giving yogurt its characteristic tartness. In this investigation, Streptococcus thermophilus and Lactobacillus acidophilus are obtained from commercially available yogurt. It is important to use a yogurt that contains living cultures (a yogurt without living cultures will not work for this investigation). The yogurt will be used as a starter culture and be added to milk to produce yogurt.

The fermentation process will generate the molecules acetaldehyde and lactic acid. Lactic acid lowers the pH of milk, giving yogurt its characteristic tartness. pageData.desc: A map describing the procedural workflow of this investigation. Before beginning the investigation, you will clean your workspace, sanitize your kitchen tools and stack one foam cup inside the other for added insulation. To begin, you will measure and heat the milk to 95 degrees Celsius. Then, you will transfer the milk to a beaker and cover with plastic wrap. Next, you will place the beaker in an ice bath and cool the milk to 32 degrees Celsius. Then, you will pour the milk into the foam cups, add the store-bought yogurt and cover the cup. Next, you will incubate the cup in a warm location. While incubating, measure the pH of the milk and store-bought yogurt. As the yogurt mixture incubates, you will measure the pH and describe it every hour until the yogurt has thickened.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.<span className=bodyParaLineBreak>For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: What is the fermentable sugar found in milk?
Which statement about fermentation in milk is NOT correct?

options.text: Fermentation is a metabolic process that uses sugars for energy.
Fermentation lowers the pH of milk.
During fermentation, an enzyme is used to break down sugar in milk.
Fermentation of milk yields acetaldehyde and lactic acid.

assestmentData.question: What is the role of lactase in yogurt production?

options.text: It is the enzyme that breaks down lactose.
It is the enzyme that breaks down galactose.
It is the enzyme that breaks down glucose.
It is the enzyme that breaks down casein.
It is an enzyme that forms casein.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result
pageData.text: Congratulations!!! You passed the Pre-lab Assessment.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result
pageData.text: You have not passed the pre-lab assessment. You must score 100% to unlock the rest of the investigation. Please review the pre-lab sections again before re-attempting this assessment. You have unlimited attempts to pass this assessment. Click the Review Pre-Lab button to be returned to the start of the pre-lab section.
Clean and sanitize the work area. You may use soap and warm water, and/or a commercial kitchen sanitizing product.
Wash the whisk, thermometer, and saucepan with soap and water. Make sure to rinse thoroughly with warm water and allow to dry completely (or dry with paper towels).
Take the two foam cups, and stack them together. This will give you a double thicknesses of foam to help provide insulation during the incubation process.

In Activity 1, you will sterilize milk before adding to it a sample of yogurt. You will then incubate the mixture in a warm location. You will then test the mixture for pH and degree of thickening every hour for several hours until yogurt has formed.
Using the beaker, measure 300 mL of milk and add the milk to the saucepan. Rinse and dry the beaker, and set it aside for later use.
Turn the stove burner to medium-low and put the saucepan on the burner.

Slowly heat the milk until it reaches 95°C, using the thermometer to monitor the temperature. Insert the thermometer in the milk, making sure the thermometer does not touch the bottom of the saucepan. To do this, hold the thermometer in one hand while in use. Do not let the milk boil because this destroys the sugars. Use the whisk to prevent the milk from sticking to the bottom of the pan.
As soon as the milk reaches 95° C, remove the saucepan from the heat source.
Transfer the milk to the beaker and insert the thermometer in the beaker.
Cover the beaker loosely with plastic wrap. Puncture the plastic wrap several times to allow steam to escape.
Fill the ice container with a few inches of water, enough to go half way up the beaker, and add ice to the water. Place the beaker in the ice water.

Every few minutes, pull back the plastic wrap, stir the milk with a plastic spoon, and measure the temperature of the milk. As soon as it reaches 32° C, pour the milk into the double-stacked foam cup. Leave approximately 1 inch of space from the top of the cup. You will still have milk left over; set it aside for the time being.
Get the yogurt from the refrigerator. Using the other plastic spoon, add 1 spoonful of refrigerated yogurt to the cup and stir it into the milk.
Cover the cup with a new piece of plastic wrap. Put a rubber band over the plastic to hold it in place.
Put the cup in a warm spot, preferably at approximately 35° C. However, any temperature above 20° C will do.
Note: If you have an oven, you can incubate in the oven with the light turned on. Just remember not to turn the oven on without removing the yogurt culture first.

Use the pH strips to measure the pH of the leftover milk (which can then be poured down the sink), the store-bought yogurt, and the new yogurt culture. Record these data in Data Table 1 along with a short description of the appearance, texture, and odor of each.
Take a photo of the milk and both yogurts.

At hourly intervals, examine the yogurt culture and gauge anything you observe. Use the pH strips to note the pH of the culture. Record these data in Data Table 1. In addition, take a photo of the new yogurt culture at each hour.

After 5 hours, the culture should have started to thicken (thickening will start sooner if the temperature is close to 35° C). Eventually, the thickened yogurt will take on a distinctive cheesy/sour smell. If incubated at 35° C, stop the culture after 8 hours. If incubated at a lower temperature, extend the incubation until 24 hours have passed. There is no need to make hourly observations after 8 hours of incubation, but be sure to take a photo and make detailed observations at 24 hours.

text: Discard all yogurt cultures in household garbage.
Dismantle the setup and clean the work area as before.
Wash your hands thoroughly with soap and warm water.

A map describing the procedural workflow of this investigation. Before beginning the investigation, you will clean your workspace, sanitize your kitchen tools and stack one foam cup inside the other for added insulation. To begin, you will measure and heat the milk to 95 degrees Celsius. Then, you will transfer the milk to a beaker and cover with plastic wrap. Next, you will place the beaker in an ice bath and cool the milk to 32 degrees Celsius. Then, you will pour the milk into the foam cups, add the store-bought yogurt and cover the cup. Next, you will incubate the cup in a warm location. While incubating, measure the pH of the milk and store-bought yogurt. As the yogurt mixture incubates, you will measure the pH and describe it every hour until the yogurt has thickened.

data.title: Acetaldehyde
data.content: A colorless volatile liquid aldehyde obtained by oxidizing ethanol

data.title: Curd
data.content: A soft, white substance formed when milk ferments

data.title: Fermentation
data.content: A metabolic process that produces chemical changes in organic substrates through the action of enzymes in the absence of oxygen; unlike cellular respiration, it does not go through the citric acid cycle and electron transport chain

data.title: Galactose
data.content: One of a group of carbohydrates known as simple sugars

data.title: Glucose
data.content: One of a group of carbohydrates known as simple sugars

data.title: Lactase
data.content: An enzyme that breaks down lactose during fermentation

data.title: Lactic acid
data.content: A colorless organic acid formed during milk fermentation and produced in the muscle tissues during strenous exercise

data.title: Lactose
data.content: A natural sugar found in milk formed by the joining of glucose and galactose

data.title: Pasteurization
data.content: The process of heat-treating beverages that kills most microbes

data.title: Whey
data.content: The watery part of milk that remains after the formation of curds
